description.narrative: Significant Direct Contribution to Poverty Reduction: IFCs proposed project will support PCHs liquidity management across its 21 bank network. In turn, this will help stabilize the network banks operations in providing financial services to MSMEs in a time of financial stress. Supporting productive small businesses will in turn stimulate growth, employment generation and poverty reduction (ProCredit banks currently provide access to financial services to nearly 1 million MSMEs). Scaling Up Microfinance: By supporting an institution sponsored by ProCredit, this project will help scale up microfinance institutions operating in LAC, ECA and Africa. The proposed product for the parent company will allow the institutions to tap into PCH in times of liquidity shortfall. If utilized, the proposed project will enable the group to further their deposit mobilization (which is the source of the volatility), and enable them to manage their liquidity to maximize on-lending. Demonstration Effect: This project will provide a signaling effect to stakeholders in the markets where ProCredit operates and provide comfort to its MSME clients if PCH activates the line. PCH will be able to tap into the IFC line and quickly inject liquidity in situations where a subsidiary faces a liquidity shortfall.

The proposed project consists of a Liquidity Line that can be used by PCH for particular subsidiaries for short-term liquidity management. IFC proposes to offer a EUR 25 million Liquidity Line which will allow PCH to have liquidity in the correct subsidiaries. While some subsidiaries are quite liquid, others could be vulnerable to temporary liquidity constraints in particular markets. PCH would be able to tap into the IFC line and quickly inject liquidity in situations where a subsidiary faces a liquidity shortfall. ProCredit Banks have exhibited their ability to recover from liquidity pressures in recent crises (Georgia and Ukraine).
